componenttext: Good morning. My name is Matthew and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the PPL Corporation First Quarter Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Joe Bergstein, Director of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the PPL conference call on first quarter results and are general business outlook. We're providing slides for this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in his presentation abo
componenttext: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the PPL conference call on first quarter results and are general business outlook. We're providing slides for this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in his presentation about future operating results or other future events are forward-looking statements under the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from such forward-looking statements. A discussion of factors that could cause actual results or events to Barry is contained in the appendix to this presentation and in the company's SEC filings. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill Spence, PPL Chairman, President and CEO.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today. We appreciate your continued interest in PPL and as always we look forward to answering your questions. To facilitate more interaction on these calls, we're going to be convi
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today. We appreciate your continued interest in PPL and as always we look forward to answering your questions. To facilitate more interaction on these calls, we're going to be convincing our prepared remarks today and we also have all 4 business unit presidents with us for the Q&A. Joining us today are, President and Chief Executive Officer of LG&E KU, which is our Kentucky regulated segment; Rick, President of PPL Global who has responsibility for our United Kingdom regulated segments and our Energy Services business; Greg Duncan, President of PPL Electric Utilities, our Pennsylvania regulated segment; and Dave, President of our competitive market supply segment; and of course Paul Farr is joining us, our CFO. 
First I'll kick off the call with an overview of our first quarter results and operational highlights for the first 3 months of the year then Paul will provide more details on our segment performance for the quarter. Following his remarks, we'll turn to your questions. With that, let's go ahead and get started. Today we announced reported first quarter earnings of $0.93 per share, up from $0.82 in the first quarter of 2011. Earnings from ongoing operations for the quarter were $0.70 per share compared with $0.84 a share in the same period last year. 
Our first quarter earnings from ongoing operations reflect $0.14 per share of dilution from our April 2011 common stock issuance to finance our acquisition of the Midlands utilities in the U.K.  As you can see in our segment results for the quarter we have very strong performance in the U.K., including the successful integration of the Midlands operations. This quarterly results demonstrate the value of our expansion and to diversify regulatory jurisdiction and the attainment of a more predictable earnings profile. 
While our competitive supply segment has become a relatively smaller piece of the pie, our supply team continues to successfully navigate through these very challenging commodity markets. Paul will go into additional details on a segment-by-segment basis but the weather-driven weakness in our domestic regulated business were offset by the strength of our U.K. operations and very good Supply segment performance. 
So despite the impact of the mild winter, our first quarter results keep us solidly on track to achieve our 2012 earnings forecasts. Today we are reaffirming our forecast of $2.11 or rather $2.15 to $2.45 per share in earnings from ongoing operations. Now let's turn to a brief operational overview for the quarter. Starting in the U.K., Western Power Distribution has fully integrated the Midlands operation on schedule and within budget. 
As you can see from the slides in the appendix to today's presentation, WPD employees have already made dramatic improvements in performance resulting in material benefits not only for our customers but for our shareholders as well. Our current assessment in the case that annual cash cost savings for the maintenance operations will be higher than what we projected during the acquisition announcement and equity financing last spring. 
These cost reductions are not coming at the expense of customer service, rather just the opposite. In just 12 months Midlands customers have seen a 40% reduction in customer minutes lost and important measure of performance in the U.K. We've also accomplish a 96% reduction in customers out of service for more than 18 hours, a 26% improvement in the number of customers restored in just 1 hour and a 22% improvement in the number of interruptions per 100 customers. 
These customer service performance improvements will result in additional incentive revenues in the future for WPD. We also believe that these improvements will further cement WPD's reputation as the gold standard for net operations in the U.K. We recently received some very good Susquehanna-Roseland Transmission Line project. National Park Service confirmed our preferred route to the Delaware water gap as the most desirable alternative. 
We expect a final record of decision for the national park service in October. This timing it will allow us to have the line is service to meet the 2015 PJM peak demand. In our competitive supply business, we completed the acquisition of a 700 megawatt gas-fired power plant in central Pennsylvania. The purchase of the AES plant represented an excellent opportunity for us to expand our gas fleet at an attractive valuation and in our own backyard. 
All of our competitive power plants had high availability during the quarter, and our gas-fired units saw increased run times as a result of low natural gas prices and a displacement of higher cost coal units. Our combined cycle gas units are already seeing close to maximum run times. For example, our lower Mount Bethel [ph] was operating at a 92% capacity factor in the first quarter. Ironwood had very strong numbers as well but that unit underwent a plant outage during a portion of the quarter. Our 
energy market and trading operations is driving value from these assets through our expert knowledge of market dynamics. Our team has done an excellent job in job capturing value and excuting hedges at the right time and as you can see on our hedge disclosure slide in the appendix, we've updated it to reflect that to show results through the first quarter, and the termination of the southern Montana contract. The modest change in coal prices reflects the lower coal burns this year shifting some of the deliveries to next year. 
Our hedge levels for power in 2014 are not materially different from the 10% to 20% we discussed on our year end call in early February. We have chosen to keep our hedging at this level because we don't see value locking in prices that we think are currently artificially low. We continue to believe that current power prices did not appropriately reflect the cost of pie with mass and CSAPR rules were all anticipated coal plant closures. 
We also believe we can see even further heat rate expansion as gas and power prices continue to decouple in the forward years. Finally we see current forwards being disproportionately affected by the short term weather, economic and gas market dynamics. These factors and the competitiveness of our mid Atlantic fleet lead us to believe that there is more upside opportunity for 2014 than downside risk at this point. 
On the nuclear front Susquehanna Unit 1 is in the midst of its refueling outage. You may have seen our recent press release indicating we've identified several cracks in low pressure turbine blades on Unit 1 and we'll be scheduling an inspection of unit 2 turbine blades as well. As we said in our release the financial impact of these replacements is not expected to be material. 
Moving now to the Pennsylvania regulated segment, I'll provide you with a summary of the distribution rate case increase request that PPL Electric Utilities filed with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission just at the end of March. We expect that any approved increase will go into effect January 12013. Slide 7 provide some details of the request. We expect the PUC, following its normal procedure to announce its plans to conduct a formal proceeding on the request. These proceedings will include technical and public input hearings during the summer, an administrative law judge recommend a decision in the fall and a final PUC vote, which is expected in December. 
As indicated on the slide, a 1% change in the allowed ROE amounts to about $23 million in revenue. This case does not include any request for alternative rate treatment or a mechanism other than the Pennsylvania act 11 law. That law does not permit filing of disks before January 1, 2013. As always we'll keep you posted on the rate case developments and we provided a docket number here so you can follow the proceeding. 
As I mentioned earlier, our first quarter results provide us with additional validation of the robustness of PPL's current portfolio. Because of the geographic and regulatory diversity of our business, we remain on track to achieve our earnings forecasts despite some of the mildest winter weather that our domestic utilities have ever seen. Over the past several months I've been asked numerous times about potential changes in the company strategy under my leadership of PPL. 
I've obviously been very involved in our strategic direction for some time and I believe time as proven they value of the steps in taken over the past several years. Going forward, our focus is going to be on delivering high quality service to our customers the remaining flexible and our competitive supply business to respond dynamic market conditions. I believe our current business mix is one of the most attractive in the sector as we have significant growth opportunities in each of our regulated business segments and a very competitive generation fleet. 
With 70% of our 2012 ongoing earnings coming from growing rate regulated businesses, we have a very solid platform for continued growth. We're forecasting compound annual rate base growth of about 8% over the next 5 years in our utility operations in the U.S. and the U.K. The resulting $8 billion of net rate base growth will come from infrastructure investments, much of which have already been approved by regulatory agencies or recovered in formulary. This includes to improve environmental cost recovery spending in Kentucky, our approved capital spending in the U.K. through early 2015 and transmission projects in the U.S. We also receive regulatory approval yesterday from the Kentucky Public Service Commission to both acquire and build gas-fired generation in Kentucky. 
Our regulated utilities are recognized for high-quality customer service, excellent reliability and positive storm response, which as you know are keys to successful long-term regulatory relationships and customer satisfaction. PPL will continue to be sharply focused on these important areas. While many of us await improved fundamentals in the electric commodity sector, PPL's favorable mix of nuclear, coal, gas and hydro facilities gives us flexibility in the current market and will provide significant upside potential when markets ultimately recover. 
In summary, I continue to believe that PPL's current strategic position is a compelling one and our focus will be on the execution and delivery of the commitment that we made to customers in our shareholders. I'll look forward to your questions following Paul's comments. Paul?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill and good morning, everyone. Before I provide details of the earnings drivers for the first quarter, I first want to discuss the equity financing that we completed in early April through a forward transaction. This offering combined with our e
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill and good morning, everyone. Before I provide details of the earnings drivers for the first quarter, I first want to discuss the equity financing that we completed in early April through a forward transaction. This offering combined with our existing management comp programs fulfill the $350 million of equity need for the year that we have consistently communicated. 
We decided to issue the stock through the use of a forward contract in order to de-risk the exposure we have and accomplish that without affecting the expectations we set regarding share count and EPS for the year. In fact, the EPS impact is actually pushed out slightly beyond the late 2012 timeframe that we have recently communicated to you. As part of our internal comprehensive risk management program and for the same reasons we have generation fuel interest rates are currency for known exposures we use this forward transaction to mitigate risk around our equity need. 
Beyond the derisking benefit we also wanted to meet a potential overhang on the stock with several of you have recently voiced as a concern. Given the current state of commodity markets there's been concern that we may need additional equity beyond the $350 million previously communicated. We do not. 
The regulated acquisition we completed combined with modest and most equity to fund rate base growth provide credit stability that will help us endure prolonged weak commodity markets. With that, let's move to Slide 8 to review our first quarter results. PPL's first quarter earnings from ongoing operations are down from a year ago driven by $0.14 per share of dilution associated with the April issue last year of common stock to finance the Midlands acquisition. 
Lower energy margins at the supply segment and lower electricity due to the extremely mild weather experience in our U.S. service territories. These negative drivers were significantly offset by strong operating results in the U.K., including the Midlands operations and we acquired April 1 of last year. Let's turn to the Kentucky regulated segment earnings drivers on Slide 9. Our Kentucky regulated segment earned $0.06 in the first quarter, a$0.09 decrease compared to last year. This decrease was primarily driven by lower margins due to lower retail electric volumes from mild weather, which impacted margins by $0.03, as well as lower operations systems sales. 
We had higher O&M primarily due to the increased scope of scheduled generation outages in 2012, higher depreciation due to higher plant and service and dilution of $0.01 per share. Moving to Slide 10, our U.K. regulated segment earned of $0.31 per share in the first quarter, a 15% increase over last year. The increase was due to the operating results of the Midlands utilities, net of interest expense associated with the 2011 equity units and higher delivery margins in our legacy WPD operation primarily driven by net impact of higher prices and lower volumes. 
These positive earnings drivers were partially offset by higher O&M, including higher pension expense higher U.S. income taxes and dilution of $0.06 per share. Turning now to our Pennsylvania regulated segment on Slide 11. This segment earned $0.06 per share in the first quarter, a $0.05 decrease compared to a year ago. This decrease was the net result of lower delivery margins of $0.02 primarily due to unseasonably mild weather, modestly higher O&M, higher depreciation again due to higher plant and service and dilution of $0.01 per share. 
Moving now to Slide 12, our Supply segment earned $0.27 per share in the first quarter, a decrease of $0.15 compared to last year. This decrease was primarily the net result of lower Eastern energy margins driven by both lower energy and capacity prices and partially offset by higher nuclear generation. Higher O&M lower income taxes primarily due to a lower state effective tax rate, and finally dilution of $0.06 per share. 
And with that, by way of review, I'd like to turn the call back to Bill for the Q&A period.

componenttext: Sure well, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we are thinking that at least at this point the MATS and CSAPR impacts are not appropriately reflected. I think we'll probably learn a lot, Dan, potentially the capacity auction when the results come out and see what units are actually going to be retired but beyond that, there is a point of which we're going to begin to hedge in. We won't be completely open until we get to 2014. So I think as we've done in the past, we have a fairly disciplined hedging program. We have plenty of time at the moment to make those decisions and pick our spots whether it's in and I think in the past, you've done a really great job of picking those times to hedge in. So I think we're going to have an opportunity and if it gets too late in the process, we'll begin to selectively hedge in.

componenttext: Okay. I really break it into 2 component pieces, Kit. We will be getting incremental cash of roughly $2 billion over the next 2 years from the conversion of the converts. So that equity will provide a meaningful delivering of supply and results in incremental cash to the company. On top of that, we think we'll still need roughly $350 million per year for the next several years as we make our way especially through the large rate base building Kentucky and after that program, it's complete the cash flows are relatively robust there, the CapEx programs, I would look at kind of projecting for the levels of the spend that we got in both EU and in WPD. There are strong opportunities and needs to put capital to work there but the big building Kentucky does have some finite into it. So I think we got plenty of equity opportunity just given how we finance the 2 acquisitions and then later in that $350 million per year that we talked about at least for the next several years.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think what I'm really referring there is a correlation between gas and power, which had been historically in the last decade or so very strong, is already beginning to break down so you're seeing improved heat rates particularly on gas units of co
componenttext: Sure. I think what I'm really referring there is a correlation between gas and power, which had been historically in the last decade or so very strong, is already beginning to break down so you're seeing improved heat rates particularly on gas units of course and what you're seeing there is the fundamentals of the power side beginning to take over just the strict correlation of the marginal fuel in PJM. So as more units are being retired and supply and demand come in to closer balance, we're really seeing the fundamentals of the power market driving power prices not just fuel input such as natural gas.

componenttext: I would say it is probably not meaningful or material from a coal burn or coal cost input side. There is Billy or pushing out of coal into next year because we're not burning at this year. To provide anymore color on that. If you would Dave?

componenttext: Paul, we're working very hard with our suppliers on a number of fronts, deferrals, altering the mix and consumption schedule for the balance of 2012 and making some adjustments. componenttext: No, it will go beyond that Paul, the primary rates relates to some correlation breakdown in our Eastern hedges, from a FAS 133 perspective, there's still very good hedges from an economic and risk perspective and so we'll match those periods as those contracts deliver and it's 2012 and 2013 primarily.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to focus on Susquehanna nuclear plant and how long do you think to down for inspection and if you guys if you do see the cracks, will you guys put blades in or will it be a de-rate of the unit?
componenttext: I want to focus on Susquehanna nuclear plant and how long do you think to down for inspection and if you guys if you do see the cracks, will you guys put blades in or will it be a de-rate of the unit?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, we would absolutely replace the blades. We would probably not do a de-rate but I'll ask Dave DeCampli to talk about the timing of the unit 2 outage.
componenttext: First, we would absolutely replace the blades. We would probably not do a de-rate but I'll ask Dave DeCampli to talk about the timing of the unit 2 outage.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Unit 2 outage is scheduled later this month and we expect it to be somewhere around 20 days and that will be dependent upon what we find in the turbine. We do have the blade available on standby to replace. We've gotten rather efficient at the inspection
componenttext: Unit 2 outage is scheduled later this month and we expect it to be somewhere around 20 days and that will be dependent upon what we find in the turbine. We do have the blade available on standby to replace. We've gotten rather efficient at the inspection process at this point so we're thinking it will be somewhere about 20 days depending on what we find once we get into the turbine.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Does the 20 day include if you had to replace the blades or 20 days of inspection and blade replacement will be incremental?
componenttext: Does the 20 day include if you had to replace the blades or 20 days of inspection and blade replacement will be incremental?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: The inspection process the first 10 days once the unit cools down and we gain access to it and then replacement will be very dependent upon whether we have to pull the turbine out of its saddle or not and we'll have to do with the number of blades that we
componenttext: The inspection process the first 10 days once the unit cools down and we gain access to it and then replacement will be very dependent upon whether we have to pull the turbine out of its saddle or not and we'll have to do with the number of blades that we find cracked. So on the short end, it would be 20 days.

componenttext: Excellent. And broadly speaking, what are you seeing in terms of the coal side in terms of the capacity factors for the balance of the year. You would think intuitively -- gas switching would somewhat alleviate in the summer months, just kind of what kind of capacity factors are you seeing on your baseload units?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes correct I think for the summer months we're going to see the coal units return to their traditional baseload operation. I think in the fall of course it's all going to be dependent upon natural gas prices, as well as coal prices but I would expect tha
componenttext: Yes correct I think for the summer months we're going to see the coal units return to their traditional baseload operation. I think in the fall of course it's all going to be dependent upon natural gas prices, as well as coal prices but I would expect that we would see hopefully financial normal weather, you'll see more run time that we signed the first quarter but with a current natural gas price to coal price relationship, I would expect that the capacity tractors less than what we've historically seen but probably not as bad as the first quarter.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: You guys have commented a little bit about O&M hit this year. Just curious to the extent to which you run your coal plants less, how much of an O&M benefit could we potentially see there, we heard some other companies discuss that.
componenttext: You guys have commented a little bit about O&M hit this year. Just curious to the extent to which you run your coal plants less, how much of an O&M benefit could we potentially see there, we heard some other companies discuss that.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: There is an O&M benefit when you're off-line and there's also a margin benefit when we are highly hedged as we are there were essentially able to buy power cheaper than we can produce it at those coal facilities so there's a -- effect there, if you will,
componenttext: There is an O&M benefit when you're off-line and there's also a margin benefit when we are highly hedged as we are there were essentially able to buy power cheaper than we can produce it at those coal facilities so there's a -- effect there, if you will, that did help us in the first quarter, and could help us in the fall as well if we see similar conditions. As far as an exact number on the O&M. I don't know that it would be that material that I could say that, that would be measured in pennies, probably not nickels and dimes.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: Well of course it's all dependent on where we can place the power that otherwise was contracted for by southern Montana. But having said that, I would say again it's one of those things that's not extremely material and as we mentioned we're maintaining and are comfortable with the midpoint of our earnings.

componenttext: I guess a follow-up on Susquehanna, you said minimal impact but is that as we sit today and if it does require a teardown and take the turbines out, could it be more than immaterial?

componenttextpreview: At this point, I don't anticipate that, no. It could be of course I can't say it couldn't be. But based on what we found on Unit 1 and the fact that the Unit 2 blades are relatively new, having been replaced last summer, I wouldn't anticipate that we're g
componenttext: At this point, I don't anticipate that, no. It could be of course I can't say it couldn't be. But based on what we found on Unit 1 and the fact that the Unit 2 blades are relatively new, having been replaced last summer, I wouldn't anticipate that we're going to get into a situation that's significantly different from Unit 1 where we essentially replaced one row of blades. So that would be in my view kind of the expectation would be if we get in there and find some damage, we'd be looking at replacing one row of blades.

componenttext: Well just my thought is if you have a favorable hedge like this and you ended up for accounting having to book the benefit upfront when we see the hedge flow-through in '12 and '13, is the hedge effectively kind of gone. Could you book that benefit upfront?

componenttext: I mean ultimately all these contracts will go to delivery we fully expect them to and we'll settle at the contracted prices, so the intervening mark-to-market up and down, which would normally be on the balance sheet, only that hits the P&L, we've carved it out. So you won't see the loss in the future either, if you will, in the same way that the benefits been carved out so would move the movement back to contracted price.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, what are you seeing in your region regarding basis both in the quarter but also kind of forward are you still kind of that flat basis any update there.
componenttext: Okay. Secondly, what are you seeing in your region regarding basis both in the quarter but also kind of forward are you still kind of that flat basis any update there.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: We saw in the first quarter about a negative $2 basis. Obviously there's the weather and natural gas prices and West Hub prices had a significant impact on that number. I guess, the drivers that I had mentioned on previous calls that move the basis around
componenttext: We saw in the first quarter about a negative $2 basis. Obviously there's the weather and natural gas prices and West Hub prices had a significant impact on that number. I guess, the drivers that I had mentioned on previous calls that move the basis around natural gas prices transmission outages, new lines coming in et cetera, all are still in play and theres' an awful lot of transmission work being done in regions throughout the region. So I think our expectation is to still see some pressure on basis, the upcoming months and through the rest of this year. We'll have to reassess after the summer where we think basis is going to travel but for now, we think that negative $2 is what delivered in the first quarter, and it's going to continue to have some pressure. Now the good news, Steve, is that we've had some very affective hedges in place that have helped offset that for us. So from an impact to PPL, it was really neutral during the quarter, even though have we been unhedged it would have been a negative $2.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay and then just finally a follow-up on coal, maybe a little more color on where your coal inventories stand in the various regions?
componenttext: Okay and then just finally a follow-up on coal, maybe a little more color on where your coal inventories stand in the various regions?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure I mean like a lot of folks, we have built up quite a bit of inventory but we still have room to grow at our stations so it's not a pressing issue for us at this moment and many of our units are back online as we speak. So we're going to be bringing t
componenttext: Sure I mean like a lot of folks, we have built up quite a bit of inventory but we still have room to grow at our stations so it's not a pressing issue for us at this moment and many of our units are back online as we speak. So we're going to be bringing the old file probably down again a little bit but we've been pretty effective and I think differing some deliveries, we worked very closely with our coal suppliers to really managed inventories during this time. And then I think as you know it in the West the coal strip in some mind mount plant so we don't have the same issues out there in terms of inventories as we do in the East.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Raymond Leung with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Raymond Leung with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Paul mentioned that proceeds from the converts that $2 billion and you also mentioned about deleveraging supply. Can you sort of give us some context of what you think is the right leverage metrics for supply? And then also staying on supply, a so
componenttext: I think Paul mentioned that proceeds from the converts that $2 billion and you also mentioned about deleveraging supply. Can you sort of give us some context of what you think is the right leverage metrics for supply? And then also staying on supply, a sort of look at your business, obviously a transformed into more regulated how should we think about longer-term generation business as part of the overall family.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me tackle the credit one and Bill can comment on the more strategic perspective of generation. From a credit perspective, as I indicated, we've got $1.15 billion that's converting in mid-'13 we've got $950 million converting in April of '14 rela
componenttext: Okay, let me tackle the credit one and Bill can comment on the more strategic perspective of generation. From a credit perspective, as I indicated, we've got $1.15 billion that's converting in mid-'13 we've got $950 million converting in April of '14 related to the equity converts as part of the off deals affectively what will happen is that equity happens at the core, if you will, and will get injected into supply allowing supply to delever. The 2 rating agencies, I'll talk about the 3 but S&P, I'll talk about 2 in the 3, S&P looks at PPL on a consolidated credit basis and so they look at consolidated FFO and consolidated debt. That movement down to supply would be effectively inconsequential to the -- which is effectively taking that supply and moving it up the quarter. And in all this, we're trying to maintain investment grade credit ratings obviously for supply, which enables us to get liquidity at reasonable prices to do the hedging. For Moody's they require from us on entity by entity basis and I think I won't speak for them but if we can maintain 20%-ish FFO the debt metrics I think we can maintain investment grade. We'd like to be more robust and I think by the time we get out a couple of years, we'll see some of the fundamental benefits that Bill talked about in terms of power prices, in terms of capacity margins in that will clearly provide opportunity for the fleet. On a year by year basis, you can look at things, they may look a little tight but I think you can put it in reasonable enough time horizon and with the amount of incremental small equity needs that I talked about year-on-year, we can manage through this.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: On your question on the competitive generation fleets, as I think about it, scale we have that given the mix of generation is very good. We are in a very good market here at PJM a very visible prices and of course, impairment capacity market. We have to k
componenttext: On your question on the competitive generation fleets, as I think about it, scale we have that given the mix of generation is very good. We are in a very good market here at PJM a very visible prices and of course, impairment capacity market. We have to keep in mind even if you are not looking at the competitive generation, we still have a thousand megawatts over 8,000 of regulated generation in Kentucky. So we have a sizable fleet around 20,000 megawatts so we do have the scale in good markets and I think as Paul mentioned earlier, we have the ability to weather the down cycles now with the commodity cycle because of the robustness of the regulated businesses. So overall, I've feel like it's if it for the company to continues to be a fit for the company and potential upside as the go into the future. And just a final now from an environmental perspective, I think you're aware that on a competitive fleet side, we're very well equipped to deal with them back to the CSAPR we're not looking at any major new incremental investments of environmental side.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: One follow-up question for Paul. Would you look at if you were to reduce debt and supply, would it be more just a mature, or would you do something a little more proactively their.

componenttext: Will probably look at as things mature, and as the closing of the construction programs in the next 12 months or so around both rainbow and hold was so that growth CapEx, if you will, kind of goes away. Our teams are looking very hard I think we talked about in the past that affecting roughly of a 5-year plan around $500 million of CapEx from that segments. We're continuing as power prices have come down to continue to look at O&M and CapEx to try to help alleviate some of the stress as well do the markets the value the plant quite as highly and new have CapEx in like to make sure that they are available but would it be available in these challenging markets assuming our way through that market cycle.

componenttext: To supplement those comments so the rate case that we're filing on that we filed in March will become effective January 1 and that's based on our 2012 capital and O&M projection. And then should we need another base rate increase in the future year, numeral 2 most likely euthanize our future test year is the way to do that.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Under the new law of you will entities can't file for the disc until 1113 and you need to have an adjudicator in ROE to be able to make that filing so the general rate case that we filed this year that these of a done and from a timing perspective we can
componenttext: Under the new law of you will entities can't file for the disc until 1113 and you need to have an adjudicator in ROE to be able to make that filing so the general rate case that we filed this year that these of a done and from a timing perspective we can file beginning 1113 and will be lucky to do that.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: I think Brian what we would do is we look at when we get into next year, we look at the outcome from the current rate case. componenttext: Regarding the regulatory process in the U.K., the real process that we have established uses full speed ahead with the transmission and the gas distribution and gas transmission sectors for the electricity distribution sector we are in a very early stages and though stages are really around policy development right now, stakeholder engagement, we will see a strategy document consultation likely issued in the fall should by Ofgem and decision documented and perhaps, the first quarter of 2013 who will start preparing our business plans for submittal may June 13 timeframe and that Ofgem will decide further innovate '13 as to do and of that agile distribution business plans that have been submitted while they be eligible or complete and robust enough to be fast track to the process and you will see some publications of that probably in late '13 and a final decision on electricity distribution fast tracks in early 14 and again, our rates will be effective in first April 2015. You have seen recently Ofgem Andrew transmission rate case price controlled release, they have fast track to the Scottish transmission companies so we view that very positively and that the process is working. It allows those business plans to move forward and say about a year in the regulatory cycle for the price control review.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the PPL conference call on first quarter results and our general business outlook. We are providing slides for this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in this presentation,
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the PPL conference call on first quarter results and our general business outlook. We are providing slides for this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in this presentation, about future operating results or other future events, are forward-looking statements under the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from such forward-looking statements. A discussion of factors that could cause actual results or events to vary is contained in the appendix to this presentation and in the company's SEC filings.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill Spence, PPL Chairman, President and CEO.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today. We appreciate your continued interest in PPL, and as always, we look forward to answering your questions. To facilitate more interaction on these calls, we're going to be con
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today. We appreciate your continued interest in PPL, and as always, we look forward to answering your questions. To facilitate more interaction on these calls, we're going to be condensing our prepared remarks today and we also have all 4 business unit presidents with us for the Q&A. Joining us today are Vic Staffieri, President and Chief Executive Officer of LG&E and KU, which is our Kentucky Regulated segment; Rick Klingensmith, President of PPL Global, who has responsibility for our United Kingdom Regulated segment and our Energy Services business; Greg Dudkin, President of PPL Electric Utilities, our Pennsylvania Regulated segment; and Dave DeCampli, President of our Competitive Market Supply segment; and of course, Paul Farr is joining us, our CFO. 
First I'll kick off the call with an overview of our first quarter results and operational highlights for the first 3 months of the year, then Paul will provide more details on our segment performance for the quarter. Following his remarks, we'll turn to your questions. With that, let's go ahead and get started.
Today we announced reported first quarter earnings of $0.93 per share, up from $0.82 in the first quarter of 2011. Earnings from ongoing operations for the quarter were $0.70 per share compared with $0.84 a share in the same period last year. Our first quarter earnings from ongoing operations reflect $0.14 per share of dilution from our April 2011 common stock issuance to finance our acquisition of the Midlands utilities in the U.K.  As you can see in our segment results for the quarter, we had very strong performance in the U.K., including the successful integration of the Midlands operations. These quarterly results demonstrate the value of our expansion and into diversified regulatory jurisdictions and the attainment of a more predictable earnings profile. While our Competitive Supply segment has become a relatively smaller piece of the pie, our Supply team continues to successfully navigate through these very challenging commodity markets. Paul will go into additional details on a segment-by-segment basis but the weather-driven weakness in our Domestic Regulated business were offset by the strength of our U.K. operations and very good Supply segment performance.
So despite the impact of the mild winter, our first quarter results keep us solidly on track to achieve our 2012 earnings forecast. Today we are reaffirming our forecast of $2.11 -- or rather, $2.15 to $2.45 per share in earnings from ongoing operations.
Now let's turn to a brief operational overview for the quarter.
Starting in the U.K., Western Power Distribution has fully integrated the Midlands operations on schedule and within budget. As you can see from the slides in the appendix to today's presentation, WPD employees have already made dramatic improvements in performance, resulting in material benefits not only for our customers but for our shareholders as well. Our current assessment in the case that annual cash cost savings, for the Midlands operations, will be higher than what we projected during the acquisition announcement and equity financing last spring.  These cost reductions are not coming at the expense of customer service, rather just the opposite. In just 12 months Midland customers have seen a 40% reduction in customer minutes lost, an important measure of performance in the U.K. We've also accomplish a 96% reduction in customers out of service for more than 18 hours, a 26% improvement in the number of customers restored in just 1 hour, and a 22% improvement in the number of interruptions per 100 customers. These customer service performance improvements will result in additional incentive revenues in the future for WPD. We also believe that these improvements will further cement WPD's reputation as the gold standard for network operations in the U.K.
We recently received some very good Susquehanna-Roseland Transmission Line project. The National Park Service confirmed our preferred route through the Delaware Water Gap as the most desirable alternative. We expect a final record of decision from the National Park Service in October. This timing it will allow us to have the line is service to meet the 2015 PJM peak demand.
In our Competitive Supply business, we completed the acquisition of a 700 megawatt gas-fired power plant in central Pennsylvania. The purchase of the AES Ironwood plant represented an excellent opportunity for us to expand our gas fleet at an attractive valuation, and in our own backyard. All of our competitive power plants had high availability during the quarter and our gas-fired units saw increased run times as a result of low natural gas prices and a displacement of higher cost coal units. Our combined cycle gas units are already seeing close to maximum run times. For example, our Lower Mount Bethel was operating at a 92% capacity factor in the first quarter. Ironwood had very strong numbers as well but that unit underwent a plant outage during a portion of the quarter.
Our energy market and trading operation is driving value from these assets through our expert knowledge of market dynamics. Our team has done an excellent job in job capturing value and executing hedges at the right time, and as you can see on our hedge disclosure slide in the appendix, we've updated it to reflect actual results through the first quarter and the termination of the Southern Montana contract. The modest change in coal prices reflects the lower coal burns this year, shifting some of the deliveries to next year. Our hedge levels for power in 2014 are not materially different from the 10% to 20% we discussed on our year end call in early February. We have chosen to keep our hedging at this level because we don't see value locking in prices that we think are, currently, artificially low. We continue to believe that current forward power prices do not appropriately reflect the cost to comply with MATS and CSAPR rules or all anticipated coal plant closures. We also believe we can see even further heat rate expansion as gas and power prices continue to decouple in the forward years.
Finally we see current forwards being disproportionately affected by the short term weather, economic and gas market dynamics. These factors and the competitiveness of our mid-Atlantic fleet lead us to believe that there is more upside opportunity for 2014, than downside risk, at this point.
On the nuclear front Susquehanna Unit 1 is in the midst of its refueling outage. You may have seen our recent press release indicating we've identified several cracks on low pressure turbine blades on Unit 1 and will be scheduling an inspection of unit 2 turbine blades as well. As we said in our release, the financial impact of these replacements is not expected to be material.
Moving now to the Pennsylvania Regulated segment.
I'll provide you with a summary of the distribution rate case increase request that PPL Electric Utilities filed with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission just at the end of March. We expect that any approved increase would go into effect January 1, 2013. Slide 7 provide some details of the request. We expect the PUC, following its normal procedure, to announce its plans to conduct a formal proceeding on the request. These proceedings will include technical and public input hearings during the summer, an administrative law judge-recommend decision in the fall and a final PUC vote, which is expected in December. As indicated on the slide, a 1% change in the allowed ROE amounts to about $23 million in revenue. This case does not include any request for alternative rate treatment or a DSIC mechanism under the new Pennsylvania Act 11 law. That law does not permit filing of DSIC before January 1, 2013.
As always we'll keep you posted on the rate case developments and we provided a docket number here so you can follow the proceeding.
As I mentioned earlier, our first quarter results provide us with additional validation of the robustness of PPL's current portfolio. Because of the geographic and regulatory diversity of our business, we remain on track to achieve our earnings forecasts despite some of the mildest winter weather that our domestic utilities have ever seen. Over the past several months I've been asked numerous times about potential changes in the company strategy under my leadership of PPL. I've obviously been very involved in our strategic direction for some time and I believe time as proven they value of the steps we've taken over the past several years. Going forward, our focus is going to be on delivering high-quality service to our customers and remaining flexible in our Competitive Supply business to respond to dynamic market conditions. I believe our current business mix is one of the most attractive in the sector as we have significant growth opportunities in each of our Regulated business segments and a very competitive generation fleet.
With 70% of our 2012 ongoing earnings coming from growing rate-regulated businesses, we have a very solid platform for continued growth. We're forecasting compound annual rate base growth of about 8% over the next 5 years in our utility operations in the U.S. and the U.K. The resulting $8 billion of net rate base growth will come from infrastructure investments, much of which have already been approved by regulatory agencies or recovered in formula rates. This includes the improved environmental cost recovery spending in Kentucky, our approved capital spending in the U.K. through early 2015 and transmission projects in the U.S. We also received regulatory approval, yesterday from the Kentucky Public Service Commission, to both acquire and build gas-fired generation in Kentucky. Our regulated utilities are recognized for high-quality customer service, excellent reliability and positive storm response which, as you know, are keys to successful long-term regulatory relationships and customer satisfaction. PPL will continue to be sharply focused on these important areas. While many of us await improved fundamentals in the electric commodity sector, PPL's favorable mix of nuclear, coal, gas and hydro facilities gives us flexibility in the current market, and will provide significant upside potential when markets ultimately recover.
In summary, I continue to believe that PPL's current strategic position is a compelling one and our focus will be on the execution and delivery of the commitments that we've made to customers in our share owners. I look forward to your questions following Paul's comments. Paul?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Before I provide details of the earnings drivers for the first quarter, I first want to discuss the equity financing that we completed in early April through a forward transaction. This offering, combined with our
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Before I provide details of the earnings drivers for the first quarter, I first want to discuss the equity financing that we completed in early April through a forward transaction. This offering, combined with our existing DRIP and management comp programs, fulfills the $350 million of equity need for the year that we have consistently communicated. We decided to issue the stock through the use of a forward contract in order to de-risk the equity exposure we had and accomplished that without affecting the expectations we set regarding share count and EPS for the year. In fact, the EPS impact is actually pushed out slightly beyond the late 2012 timeframe that we recently communicated to you. As part of our internal comprehensive risk management program and for the same reasons we had generation, output, fuel, interest rate, our currency for known exposures, we used this forward transaction to mitigate risk around our equity need. Beyond the de-risking benefit we also wanted to alleviate a potential overhang on the stock which several of you have recently voiced as a concern. Given the current state of commodity markets there has been concern that we may need additional equity beyond the $350 million previously communicated. We do not.  The regulated acquisitions we completed, combined with modest amounts of equity to fund rate base growth, provide credit stability that will help us endure prolonged weak commodity markets.
With that, let's move to Slide 8 to review our first quarter results.
PPL's first quarter earnings from ongoing operations are down from a year ago, driven by $0.14 per share of dilution associated with the April issuance, last year, of common stock to finance the Midlands acquisition; lower energy margins at the Supply segment; and lower electricity sales due to the extremely mild weather experienced in our U.S. service territories. These negative drivers were significantly offset by strong operating results in the U.K., including the Midlands operations that we acquired April 1 of last year.
Let's turn to the Kentucky Regulated segment earnings drivers on Slide 9.
Our Kentucky Regulated segment earned $0.06 per share in the first quarter, a $0.09 decrease compared to last year. This decrease was primarily driven by lower margins due to lower retail electric volumes from mild weather, which impacted margins by $0.03, as well as lower op system sales. We had higher O&M primarily due to the increased scope of scheduled generation outages in 2012, higher depreciation due to higher plant and service and dilution of $0.01 per share.
Moving to Slide 10.
Our U.K. Regulated segment earned $0.31 per share in the first quarter, a 15% increase over last year. The increase was due to the operating results of the Midlands utilities, net of interest expense associated with the 2011 equity units and higher delivery margins in our legacy WPD operation, primarily driven by the net impact of higher prices and lower volumes. These positive earnings drivers were partially offset by higher O&M, including higher pension expense; higher U.S. income taxes; and dilution of $0.06 per share.
Turning now to our Pennsylvania Regulated segment on Slide 11.
This segment earned $0.06 per share in the first quarter, a $0.05 decrease compared to a year ago. This decrease was the net result of lower delivery margins of $0.02, primarily due to unseasonably mild weather; modestly higher O&M; higher depreciation, again due to higher plant; and service and dilution of $0.01 per share.
Moving now to Slide 12.
Our Supply segment earned $0.27 per share in the first quarter, a decrease of $0.15 compared to last year. This decrease was primarily the net results of lower Eastern energy margins, driven by both lower energy and capacity prices, and partially offset by higher nuclear generation; higher O&M; lower income taxes, primarily due to a lower state effective tax rate; and finally, dilution of $0.06 per share. 
And with that, by way of review, I'd like to turn the call back to Bill for the Q&A period.

componenttext: Sure. Well, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we are thinking that, at least at this point, the MATS and CSAPR impacts are not appropriately reflected. I think we'll probably learn a lot, Dan, potentially, from the capacity auction when the results come out and see what units are actually going to be retired. But beyond that, there is a point of which we're going to begin to hedge in. We won't leave it completely open until we get to 2014. So I think, as we've done in the past, we have a fairly disciplined hedging program. We have plenty of time, at the moment, to make those decisions and pick our spots when we hedge in. And I think, in the past, we've done a really great job of picking those times to hedge in. So I think we're going to have an opportunity, and if it gets too late in the process, we'll begin to selectively hedge in.

componenttext: So on the question of equity, Paul, you were pretty clear that you're not going to need additional equity related to a tiny [ph] cash shortfall that might be arising from low commodity prices. What's the outlook over the next several years? You have a significant structural free cash flow deficit. What's the schedule for funding that with equity and how should we view it overall on how equity fits into your cash needs over the next few years?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. I really break it into 2 component pieces, Kit. We will be getting incremental cash of roughly $2 billion over the next 2 years from the conversion of the converts. So that equity will provide a meaningful de-levering of supply and results in increm
componenttext: Okay. I really break it into 2 component pieces, Kit. We will be getting incremental cash of roughly $2 billion over the next 2 years from the conversion of the converts. So that equity will provide a meaningful de-levering of supply and results in incremental cash to the company. On top of that, we think we'll still need the roughly $350 million per year, for the next several years, as we make our way, especially through the large rate-based build in Kentucky. And after that program is complete, the cash flows are relatively robust there. The CapEx programs, I would look at, kind of projecting forward, the levels of the spend that we got in both EU and in WPD. There are strong opportunities and needs to put capital to work there, but the big build in Kentucky does have some finite into it. So I think we've got plenty of equity opportunity just given how we finance the 2 acquisitions, and then later in that $350 million per year that we've talked about, at least for the next several years.

componenttext: Okay. And, Bill, at the reception in New York last month, and basically this [indiscernible], you mentioned the [indiscernible] of the gas prices for power prices. If you could elaborate on that.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think what I'm really referring there to is the correlation between gas and power which had been historically in the last decade or so, very strong, is already beginning to break down. So you're seeing improved heat rates, particularly on gas unit
componenttext: Sure. I think what I'm really referring there to is the correlation between gas and power which had been historically in the last decade or so, very strong, is already beginning to break down. So you're seeing improved heat rates, particularly on gas units, of course. And what we're seeing there is the fundamentals of the power side beginning to take over just the strict correlation of the marginal fuel in PJM. So as more units are being retired and supply and demand come in to closer balance, we're really seeing the fundamentals of the power market driving power prices not just fuel input such as natural gas.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we come from a combination of supply, which I referenced. And that was just a couple of cents of share from the lower effective state tax rate. The bigger driver, year-on-year, is going to come from the change in the business mix of the company. The
componenttext: Yes, we come from a combination of supply, which I referenced. And that was just a couple of cents of share from the lower effective state tax rate. The bigger driver, year-on-year, is going to come from the change in the business mix of the company. The U.K. effective tax rate for that segment is only 25% versus the other segment that run closer run to 35% to 37%. So just the change in the business mix is going to drive a lower effective tax rate.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then secondly, the coal burn. You mentioned that some is going to be pushed into next year. How should we be thin about that from an earnings perspective? In other words, are you deferring higher cost coal into next year's burn, so to spe
componenttext: Okay, great. And then secondly, the coal burn. You mentioned that some is going to be pushed into next year. How should we be thin about that from an earnings perspective? In other words, are you deferring higher cost coal into next year's burn, so to speak?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say, Paul, it's probably not meaningful or material from a coal burn and coal cost input side. There is delaying or pushing out of coal into next year because we're not burning it this year. I'll ask Dave DeCampli to provide anymore color on that.
componenttext: I would say, Paul, it's probably not meaningful or material from a coal burn and coal cost input side. There is delaying or pushing out of coal into next year because we're not burning it this year. I'll ask Dave DeCampli to provide anymore color on that. If you would Dave?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. We're working very hard with our suppliers on a number of fronts, deferrals, altering the mix and consumption schedule for the balance of 2012 and making some adjustments. So we're calling it not material look at this point because we're relati
componenttext: Yes, Paul. We're working very hard with our suppliers on a number of fronts, deferrals, altering the mix and consumption schedule for the balance of 2012 and making some adjustments. So we're calling it not material look at this point because we're relatively in good shape for 2012 inventories.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just finally, the mark-to-market gain that you guys are going to be realizing into 2012. That's going to begin into operating earnings, is that correct? It's being excluded from operating earnings. I guess it would've been a positive
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just finally, the mark-to-market gain that you guys are going to be realizing into 2012. That's going to begin into operating earnings, is that correct? It's being excluded from operating earnings. I guess it would've been a positive. And how is it going to impact 2012 and does it go just in 2012? Does it go beyond that?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, it'll go beyond that, Paul. Primarily, rates relates to some correlation breakdown in our Eastern hedges. From a FAS 133 perspective, there's still very good hedges from an economic and risk perspective and so we'll match those periods as those contra
componenttext: No, it'll go beyond that, Paul. Primarily, rates relates to some correlation breakdown in our Eastern hedges. From a FAS 133 perspective, there's still very good hedges from an economic and risk perspective and so we'll match those periods as those contracts deliver, and it's 2012 and 2013 primarily.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Kordell with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Kordell with Jefferies.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to focus on Susquehanna nuclear plant and how you think -- you have Unit 2 down for inspection and if you guys -- if you do see the cracks, will you guys put blades in or will it be a de-rate of the unit?
componenttext: I want to focus on Susquehanna nuclear plant and how you think -- you have Unit 2 down for inspection and if you guys -- if you do see the cracks, will you guys put blades in or will it be a de-rate of the unit?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, we would absolutely replace the blades. We would probably not do a de-rate but I'll ask Dave DeCampli to talk about the timing of the Unit 2 outage.
componenttext: First, we would absolutely replace the blades. We would probably not do a de-rate but I'll ask Dave DeCampli to talk about the timing of the Unit 2 outage.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Anthony. The Unit 2 outage is scheduled later this month and we expect it to be somewhere around 20 days and that will be dependent upon what we find in the turbine. We do have the blades available on standby to replace. We've gotten rather efficient
componenttext: Yes, Anthony. The Unit 2 outage is scheduled later this month and we expect it to be somewhere around 20 days and that will be dependent upon what we find in the turbine. We do have the blades available on standby to replace. We've gotten rather efficient at the inspection process at this point. So we're thinking it will be somewhere about 20 days, depending on what we find once we get in the turbine.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Does the 20-day outage include if you had to replace the blades or 20 days of inspection and blade replacement will be incremental?
componenttext: Does the 20-day outage include if you had to replace the blades or 20 days of inspection and blade replacement will be incremental?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Call the inspection process the first 10 days, once the unit cools down and we gain access to it. And then replacement will be very dependent upon whether we have to pull the turbine out of its saddle or not. And we'll have to do it with a number of blade
componenttext: Call the inspection process the first 10 days, once the unit cools down and we gain access to it. And then replacement will be very dependent upon whether we have to pull the turbine out of its saddle or not. And we'll have to do it with a number of blades that we find cracked. So on the short end, it would be 20 days.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: So first question, just kind of bouncing off what Public Service said the other day, are you guys into submitting higher Roseland, the Susquehanna CapEx here, just given what's happened of late, first? I didn't really see any kind of material change too much.

componenttext: Great. And then secondly, with regards to coal prices this year. It seems as if it just went up a slight hair there, $1 a ton. Is that basically, call it, payments for taking delivery at a later point in time?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: It is. It's primarily a timing issue, yes.
componenttext: It is. It's primarily a timing issue, yes.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And broadly speaking, what are you seeing on the coal side, in terms of the capacity factors for the balance of the year? You would think, intuitively, call it the gas switching would somewhat alleviate in the summer months. Just kind of what k
componenttext: Excellent. And broadly speaking, what are you seeing on the coal side, in terms of the capacity factors for the balance of the year? You would think, intuitively, call it the gas switching would somewhat alleviate in the summer months. Just kind of what kind of capacity factors are you seeing on your baseload units?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct. I think for the summer months we're going to see the coal units return to their traditional baseload operation. I think, in the fall, of course it's all going to be dependent upon natural gas prices, as well as coal prices. But I would expec
componenttext: Yes, correct. I think for the summer months we're going to see the coal units return to their traditional baseload operation. I think, in the fall, of course it's all going to be dependent upon natural gas prices, as well as coal prices. But I would expect that we would see -- hopefully, if you see normal weather, you'd see more run time that we signed the first quarter. But with the current natural gas price to coal price relationship, I would expect that the capacity factors in the fall are going to be less than what we've historically seen. But probably not as bad as the first quarter.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Interesting. And you guys have commented a little bit about O&M hit this year. Just curious, to the extent to which you run your coal plants less. How much of an O&M benefit could we potentially see there? We heard some other companies discuss that.
componenttext: Interesting. And you guys have commented a little bit about O&M hit this year. Just curious, to the extent to which you run your coal plants less. How much of an O&M benefit could we potentially see there? We heard some other companies discuss that.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is an O&M benefit when you're off-line and there's also a margin benefit when we are highly hedged, as we are. We're essentially able to buy power cheaper than we can produce it at those coal facilities. So there's a dual effect there, if you w
componenttext: Yes, there is an O&M benefit when you're off-line and there's also a margin benefit when we are highly hedged, as we are. We're essentially able to buy power cheaper than we can produce it at those coal facilities. So there's a dual effect there, if you will, that did help us in the first quarter and could help us in the fall as well if we see similar conditions. As far as an exact number on the O&M. I don't know that it would be that material, that I could say that -- that would be measured in pennies, probably not nickels and dimes.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then just the last question, sort of a small detail. The Montana contract rejection. What kind of an impact are you guys seeing there just annually?
componenttext: Right. And then just the last question, sort of a small detail. The Montana contract rejection. What kind of an impact are you guys seeing there just annually?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, it's all dependent on where we can place the power that otherwise was contracted for by southern Montana. But having said that, I would say, again, it's one of those things that's not extremely material. And as we mentioned we're maintain
componenttext: Well, of course, it's all dependent on where we can place the power that otherwise was contracted for by southern Montana. But having said that, I would say, again, it's one of those things that's not extremely material. And as we mentioned we're maintaining, and are comfortable, with the midpoint of our earnings.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: As you saw on the earnings release, the news release that came out, we have increased our forecast for this year. Up to $1.07 a share. And that incorporates the additional benefits we're seeing from the integration of the Midlands operation. And that's pretty much where we're heading out, thus far, for this year in our forecast.

componenttextpreview: Well, on the natural gas plant side?
componenttext: Well, on the natural gas plant side?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say -- I mentioned, also, that Ironwood was out on an outage for some period of time. That still saw about a 76% capacity factor during the quarter. So I would expect, with similar conditions, that we would be at a 90% type capacity factor.
componenttext: I would say -- I mentioned, also, that Ironwood was out on an outage for some period of time. That still saw about a 76% capacity factor during the quarter. So I would expect, with similar conditions, that we would be at a 90% type capacity factor.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess, a follow-up on Susquehanna. You said minimal impact, but is that as we sit today and if it does require a teardown and take the turbines out, could it be more than immaterial?
componenttext: I guess, a follow-up on Susquehanna. You said minimal impact, but is that as we sit today and if it does require a teardown and take the turbines out, could it be more than immaterial?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: At this point, I don't anticipate that, no. Could it be? Yes, of course I can't say it couldn't be. But based on what we found on Unit 1 and the fact that the Unit 2 blades are relatively new, having been replaced last summer, I wouldn't anticipate that w
componenttext: At this point, I don't anticipate that, no. Could it be? Yes, of course I can't say it couldn't be. But based on what we found on Unit 1 and the fact that the Unit 2 blades are relatively new, having been replaced last summer, I wouldn't anticipate that we're going to get into a situation that's significantly different from Unit 1, where we essentially replaced one row of blades. So that would be, in my view kind, of the expectation would be if we get in there and find some damage. We'd be looking at replacing one row of blades.

componenttext: Is this warranty work?

componenttext: The blades are under warranty and until we determine the final root cause, we'll continue to work with the vendor and work those details out.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
